questions.question:
Question 1: A patient comes with long-standing non-pitting edema in the legs. What is the most probable 
cause?
questions.explanation:
Lymphedema is the most probable cause of long-standing non-pitting edema in the limbs. Lymphedema is the abnormal accumulation of protein-rich fluid in the interstitial spaces of the 
tissues. Lymphedema can be primary or secondary. Primary lymphedema includes: • Lymphedema congenita (0-2 years): more common in males, involves multiple limbs, face, and 
genitalia. It can be familial or sporadic. The familial type is called Nonne Milroy syndrome. • Lymphedema praecox (2-35 years): more common in females, the most common type of primary 
lymphedema with a peak incidence in puberty. It can be familial or sporadic. The familial type is 
called Meig's disease. • Lymphedema tarda (>35 years): Rare and uncommon. Secondary lymphedema is more common than primary and is the most common cause of 
lymphedema overall. Causes include lymph node dissection (axillary or inguinal), 
post-mastectomy, postoperative radiotherapy, obesity, varicose vein surgery, and trauma. Complications of lymphedema include infections, skin changes, recurent cellulitis, non-healing 
ulcers, and lymphangiosarcoma. Treatment mostly includes patient education and nonsurgical interventions, which include limb 
elevation, and external compressive garments. When the above methods fail, surgery can be 1234 
Sold by @itachibot considered.

Question 4: An 8-month-old girl child was brought to the hospital with complaints of swelling of both feet 
as shown in the image. On examination pitting is seen. Her ECG, RFT, and urine analysis 
were normal. What is the true statement regarding this condition?
questions.explanation:
The patient most likely has Milroy disease which is the familial version of congenital lymphedema. 
It is inherited as a dominant trait. Primary lymphedema is classified on the basis of age of onset and the presence of familial 
clustering. • Congenital lymphoedema - onset before 2 years of age • Lymphedema precox - most common type. onset between 2 to 35 years of age • Lymphedema tarda - rare. onset after 35 years of age Treatment includes conservative management such as massage, compression stockings, or 
bandaging. Surgical management includes vascularized lymph node transfer (VLNT). It involves the transfer 
of functional lymph nodes from a healthy donor site to an area of the body with damaged or 
diseased lymphatic drainage. Features

Question 5: Which of the following will you perform when asked to do a lymphangiography of the leg? 1230 
Sold by @itachibot

options.a: Inject sodium diatrizoate subcutaneously on the dorsum of the foot
options.b: Inject sodium diatrizoate retrogradely under pressure into a small vein on the dorsum of foot
options.c: Dissect the lymphatics through an incision on the dorsum of foot and injecting contrast
options.d: Insertion of guidewire into the lymphatic system of the leg and inject contrast

questions.explanation:
1236 
Sold by @itachibot Direct contrast lymphangiography is done by dissecting the lymphatic vasculature through an 
incision on the dorsum of the foot and injecting contrast. Direct contrast lymphangiography is an invasive study done to visualise the lymphatic system. It 
involves exposure and cannulation of lymphatics and slow injection of contrast medium such 
as ethiodized oil. Complications: • Damage to the visualized lymphatics • Allergic reactions • Pulmonary embolism if the oil-based contrast agent enters the venous system through 
lymphovenous anastomosis. Contrast magnetic resonance lymphangiography is a newer testing method. It is performed after 
intracutaneous injection of gadobenate dimeglumine into the interdigital webs of the dorsal foot. It is capable of visualizing the anatomy and functional status of lymph flow transport of lymphatic 
vessels and lymph nodes of lymphedematous limbs. Image A shows a lymphangiography with normal uptake. Image B shows a lymphangiography scan with no uptake in Milroy's disease. Image C depicts a lymphangiography scan in a patient with lymphoedema and reflux.

questions.question:
Question 6: Which of the following complications are least likely to develop, in patients with chronic 
lymphoedema?
questions.explanation:
Marjolin's ulcers are unlikely to develop in patients with chronic lymphedema. Marjolin’s ulcers are malignant ulcers that develop over chronic scars, most commonly from 
burns. Marjolin's ulcer may also develop in chronic long standing venous ulcers but are not seen 
in chronic lymphedema. 1237 
Sold by @itachibot Initially, the lymphedema is soft and pits on the pressure but with time the skin becomes 
thickened and non-pitting due to fibrosis, dermal thickening, and hyperkeratosis. Frequent episodes of lymphangitis and cellulitis may occur. This is due to loss of local immune 
defense mechanisms. Chronic eczema, the fungal infection of skin and nails, fissuring, verrucae, 
and papillae (warts) are frequently seen in advanced disease. Rarely malignancy (lymphangiosarcoma or angiosarcoma) may occur in chronic lymphedema. 
This neoplastic transformation of blood vessels and lymphatics is called Stewart-Treves syndrome.

questions.question: Question 7: Which of the following statements regarding mediastinal lymphoma is false?

options.a: Middle mediastinum is the most common site of mediastinal lymphoma
options.c: Chemotherapy is the treatment of choice
options.d: Video assisted thoracoscopy is used to diagnose the condition

questions.explanation:
Anterior compartment is the most common site of lymphoma in the mediastinum. Other sites 
include the middle compartment and hilar nodes. Primary mediastinal lymphoma is an uncommon type of lymphoma. Hodgkin's lymphoma (HL), 
primary mediastinal B-cell lymphoma (PMBCL), and T-lymphoblastic lymphoma are the most 
common primary mediastinal lymphomas. In about 50% of patients who have both Hodgkin’s and 
Non-Hodgkin’s Lymphoma, the mediastinum may be the primary site. Superior vena cava (SVC) syndrome refers to symptoms produced by the obstruction of blood flow 
through the SVC by the enlarging mediastinal mass, resulting in symptoms of dyspnea, facial and 
upper-extremity edema, cough, chest pain, and dysphagia. Video-assisted thoracoscopy (VATS) is used to obtain a biopsy of the mediastinal mass for 
confirmation and diagnosis. Chemotherapy with six cycles of R-CHOP regimen is preferred. Rituximab is a chimeric 
monoclonal anti-CD20 antibody and has become a standard component of treating all B-cell 
lymphoma histologies that express CD20. Note: Thymoma is the most common mediastinal tumor in adults (overall).

questions.question:
Question 8: A 5-month-old boy is brought to the hospital with complaints of swelling in the neck as given 
in the image. Which of the following is true regarding this condition? 1231 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: It is a congenital sequestration of lymphatic channel
options.d: Sclerotherapy is not used in treatment

questions.explanation:
The given image depicts a lymphangioma, also known as cystic hygroma. They are brilliantly 
transilluminant. Lymphangiomas are congenital benign tumors of the lymphatic system. They are the isolated 
cystic mass of lymphatic tissue that has the ability to produce lymph. Over time the tumor 
enlarges due to the accumulation of lymph within the cyst. Types of lymphangiomas: • Simple or capillary lymphangioma: They occur subcutaneously in the head, neck, and axilla. 
They may also occur within the internal organs and connective tissues in the thoracic and 
abdominal cavities. • Cavernous lymphangioma or cystic hygroma: They also occur in the neck or axilla. Rarely they 
may occur in retroperitoneum. 1238 
Sold by @itachibot Treatment includes surgical excision of the tumor and image-guided sclerotherapy. If there is any residual lymphatic malformation after the treatment, then a conservative excision 
or unroofing of the cyst is done. It may be combined with sclerosing therapy or repeated partial 
excisions. Note: The terms lymphangioma and cystic hygromas are older terms. They are now called 
lymphatic malformations.

questions.question: Question 9: Where is lymphangiosarcoma most commonly seen?
questions.explanation:
Lymphangiosarcoma is most commonly seen in post-mastectomy edema of the arm. Lymphangiosarcoma is a rare tumor that develops as a complication of long-standing lymph- 
edema. Clinically, the patients present with acute worsening of the edema and appearance of 
subcutaneous nodules that have a propensity toward hemorrhage and ulceration. The tumor can be treated, like other sarcomas, with preoperative chemotherapy and radiation 
followed by surgical excision, which usually may take the form of radical amputation. Overall, 
the prognosis is very poor.

questions.question:
Question 10: A patient underwent surgery for breast carcinoma. She now presents with painless swelling 
involving the arm as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? 1232 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given clinical vignette and the image are suggestive of post-mastectomy lymphedema 
involving the upper limb. Lymphoedema occurs when interstitial fluid accumulates due to defective lymphatic drainage. It 
is a common complication of breast cancer treatment involving axillary lymph node 
dissection and radiotherapy. Sentinel lymph node dissection (SLND) reduces the risk of 1239 
Sold by @itachibot lymphedema significantly. Clinical signs and symptoms are observed in the ipsilateral arm. A significant increase in the limb 
size due to swelling is seen. Other symptoms are heaviness, tightness, numbness, tingling, limb 
fatigue, and reduced limb mobility. Diagnosis is predominantly based on the clinical swelling of the arm. The girth of the affected arm 
>2 centimeters than the normal limb, a 200-mL or more increase in limb volume, or a 5% or 
greater limb volume change are other diagnostic criteria. Management: Limb elevation, elastic arm stockings, and pneumatic compression devices can help reduce 
swelling. Dry skin can be seen due to fluid accumulation, which can lead to cellulitis/skin infections. Using 
a low pH water-based moisturizer is helpful. Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) by a therapist followed by simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) by 
the patient daily aids interstitial fluid evacuation. Benzpyrones and flavonoids are some naturally occurring substances that may be of use to treat 
lymphedema. Surgical options are lymphaticovenular anastomosis, liposuction, and debulking. Other options: Option B: Stewart-Treves syndrome refers to lymphangiosarcoma seen in chronic long-standing 
lymphedema following mastectomy (more than 10 years). They present as single/multiple 
bluish-red skin and subcutaneous nodules. They can ulcerate and hemorrhage. Option C: Axillary venous thrombosis or Paget-Schrotter disease is seen in patients doing rigorous 
exercise and in weightlifters. The subclavian vein is compressed at the thoracic outlet. Painful 
swelling of the arm is observed. Option D: Cellulitis usually presents with an ulcer and the skin is erythematous, swollen, and 
painful. Fever, chills, and rigor follow.

questions.question: Question 11: Which of the following is not a part of decongestive lymphoedema therapy (DLT)?
questions.explanation:
Diuretics and Homan’s procedure are not a part of DLT, and are a part of drug therapy and 
surgical management. Decongestive lymphoedema therapy (DLT) is the currently used method for controlling swelling in 
lymphoedema. It consists of 2 phases: intensive and maintenance. Intensive phase includes: • Skin care: Prevent drying of skin and exposure to the sun, avoid venipuncture from the affected 
limb. • Limb elevation • Manual lymphatic drainage (MLD) - Proximal massage along lymphatic channels. 1240 
Sold by @itachibot • Compression therapy: Multilayer lymphoedema bandaging (MLLB), Pneumatic lymphoedema 
stockings, Graded compression stockings (100% in the ankle/foot, 70% in the knee, 50% in 
mid-thigh, and 40% in the groin). • Exercise: Slow rhythmic isotonic movements are beneficial, while vigorous, anaerobic isometric 
exercises are to be avoided. Standard MLLB is only done if ABPI is  0.8. It is contraindicated if ABPI is < 0.5. Maintenance phase includes: • Simple lymphatic drainage (SLD) - It is a simple massage technique done by the patient. • Pain relief

questions.question: Question 12: Which among the following is not a limb reduction surgery for lymphoedema?
questions.explanation:
Kinmonth procedure is a bypass surgery done for lymphoedema not a limb reduction surgery. Surgical management of lymphoedema is divided into bypass procedures, liposuction, and limb 
reduction procedures. • Bypass procedures include: • Neilubowicz procedure - anastomosing lymph nodes to the veins. • Kinmonth procedure - using ileal mucosal patch. • Limb reduction procedures include: • Sistrunk procedure - A wedge of skin and subcutaneous tissue is excised and the wound closed 
primarily. This is the most commonly carried out procedure to reduce the girth of the thigh. • Homan’s procedure - Skin flaps are raised, and then subcutaneous tissue is excised from beneath 
the flaps. • Thompson’s procedure - Modification of Homan’s procedure. • Charles procedure - Excision of all of the skin and subcutaneous tissues down to the deep fascia, 
with coverage using split-skin grafts. 1241 
Sold by @itachibot Skin Malignancies
